title: B decays to final states including D_s^{(*)} and D^*

summary:
The e^+e^- annihilation data recorded with the BABAR detector has been used
to study B decays to D_s^(*) and D^* mesons. The production fraction of
inclusive D_s^(*) and the corresponding momentum spectra have been determined.
Exclusive decays B^0 --> D^{*-}D_s^{(*)+} have been identified with a partial
reconstruction technique and their branching fractions have been measured. We
also report branching fraction measurements for the exclusive hadronic modes
B^0 --> D^{*-} pi^+ and B^0 --> D^{*-} rho^+.

Abstract
The e+ e− annihilation data recorded with the BABAR detector has been used to study B decays

 1

Introduction
(∗)

The study of Ds production in B decays allows us to understand the mechanisms leading
to the creation of cs̄ quark pairs. The precise measurement of the momentum spectrum allows a
determination of the fraction of two-body and multi-body decay modes, and helps in understanding
(∗)±
b → cc̄s transitions. In this study we report a new measurement of the inclusive Ds
production
rate in B decays and the branching fractions of two specific two-body B decay modes involving a
(∗)±
Ds
meson. We have also studied the decay modes B 0 → D ∗− π + and B 0 → D ∗− ρ+ and measured
the corresponding branching fractions using fully-reconstructed events. Those measurements are
interesting for testing factorization models of B decays to open charm.

2

Dataset

The data were collected with the BABAR detector operating at the PEP-II storage ring at
(∗)
the Stanford Linear Accelerator Center. For the inclusive Ds production in B decays and the
(∗)+
B 0 → D ∗− Ds
branching fraction measurements we used a data sample equivalent to 7.7 fb−1
of integrated luminosity collected while running on the Υ (4S) → BB resonance and a sample of
1.2 fb−1 collected 40 MeV/c2 below the B B̄ threshold. Branching fraction measurements for the
B 0 → D ∗− π + and B 0 → D ∗− ρ+ modes use a subset corresponding to an integrated luminosity of
5.2 fb−1 .

3

Inclusive Ds(∗) Production in B Decay

The Ds± mesons are reconstructed in the Ds± → φπ ± decay mode with φ → K + K − . Particle
identification is used to obtain a clean sample. Three charged tracks coming from a common vertex
are combined to form a Ds± . Two of them, with opposite charge, are required to be positively
identified as kaons and their invariant mass must be within 8 MeV of the nominal φ mass. In
this decay the φ meson is polarized longitudinally which means the helicity angle of the decay,
θH has a cos2 θH dependence[1]. The requirement | cos θH | > 0.3 keeps 97.5% of the signal while
rejecting 30% of the background. Candidate Ds∗± mesons are reconstructed in the decay channel
Ds∗± → Ds± γ with Ds± → φπ ± . Ds± candidates are required to be within 2.5σ of the φπ invariant
mass. Photon candidates must deposit a minimum energy of 50 MeV/c2 in the calorimeter. The
number of Ds± mesons is extracted from a Gaussian fit of the φπ ± invariant mass distribution
for different momentum ranges in the Υ (4S) → BB rest frame. Similarly, the number of Ds∗± is
extracted by fitting the mass difference mDs∗ − mDs distribution. The efficiency-corrected number

4

Measurement of B 0 → D∗− Ds(∗)+ Branching Fractions

The measurement of the branching fractions for the decays B 0 → D ∗− Ds+ and B 0 → D ∗− Ds∗+
(∗)+
uses a partial reconstruction technique. The Ds
are fully reconstructed, we do not reconstruct
(∗)+
0
∗−
the D coming from the D decay. Instead, we combine a Ds
candidate with a π − and then
(∗)+
calculate missing mass assuming that the Ds
and π − originate from the same B 0 . This missing
(∗)+
0
mass should be the D mass if our hypothesis is correct. The yield of B 0 → D ∗− Ds
is evaluated
by fitting the missing mass distribution (Fig. 2) with the sum of a Gaussian and a background
function[1]. The branching fractions we measure are (7.1 ± 2.4 ± 2.5 ± 1.8) × 10−3 for the channel
B 0 → D ∗− Ds+ , and (2.5 ± 0.4 ± 0.5 ± 0.6) × 10−2 for the channel for B 0 → D ∗− Ds∗+ .

 Measurement of B 0 → D∗−π+ and B 0 → D∗−ρ+ Branching Fractions

5

B 0 candidates in the channels D ∗− π + and D ∗− ρ+ are fully reconstructed in the decay chain
→ D 0 π − , followed by D0 → K + π − . The ρ+ is reconstructed in the mode ρ+ → π + π 0 .
Event selection is based on a few simple criteria. Tracks are required to originate from near
the beam interaction point and no particle identification is used. Photons with energy grater
than 30 MeV/c2 are combined to form π 0 candidates. To form a D 0 candidate, kaons and pions
with opposite charge and originating from the same vertex must have an invariant mass within
±2.5σ of the nominal D 0 mass. The D 0 candidates are required to have a momentum grater
than 1.3 GeV/c in the Υ (4S) → BB frame and are combined with a pion to form a charged
D ∗ candidate. D ∗ candidates are required to have ∆m = m(D 0 π − ) − m(D0 ) within 2.5σ of
the nominal mass difference. Finally, we combine D ∗ candidates with a π + , with a momentum
grater than 500 MeV/c or a ρ+ candidate to form B 0 candidates. In the decay B 0 → D ∗− π +
the longitudinal polarization of the D ∗− is used to reduce background[2]. For the B 0 → D ∗− ρ+
mode, ρ+ candidates are selected requiring the π + π 0 invariant mass within 150 MeV of the ρ+
nominal mass. Event shape variables are also used to remove continuum background. For correctly

Based on the fitted yield of signal events the preliminary results for the branching fractions
for B 0 → D ∗− π + and B 0 → D ∗− ρ+ are (2.9 ± 0.3 ± 0.3) × 10−3 and (11.2 ± 1.1 ± 2.5) × 10−3 ,
respectively. The branching fraction for B 0 → D ∗− ρ+ includes all non-resonant and quasi-twobody contributions that lead to a π + π 0 invariant mass in the ρ band; however, the acceptance for
non-resonant D ∗− π + π 0 decays is about 15% of D ∗+ ρ+ . Moreover, previous measurements indicate
that the non-resonant branching fraction is comparatively small. Therefore we estimate that the
non-resonant contribution to our result is small. Both branching fraction results compare well with
previous measurements and with the world average[4].
